name: Send Whisper
description: Sends a whisper message to the specified user.
instruction: Sends a whisper message to the specified user. NOTE: The user sending the whisper must have a verified phone number (see the Phone Number setting in your Security and Privacy settings). NOTE: The API may silently drop whispers that it suspects of violating Twitch policies. (The API does not indicate that it dropped the whisper; it returns a 204 status code as if it succeeded.) Rate Limits: You may whisper to a maximum of 40 unique recipients per day. Within the per day limit, you may whisper a maximum of 3 whispers per second and a maximum of 100 whispers per minute.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:manage:whispers scope.

message.instruction:
The whisper message to send. The message must not be empty.

The maximum message lengths are:
  • 500 characters if the user you're sending the message to hasn't whispered you before.
  • 10,000 characters if the user you're sending the message to has whispered you before.
Messages that exceed the maximum length are truncated.

from_user_id.instruction: The ID of the user sending the whisper. This user must have a verified phone number. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

to_user_id.instruction: The ID of the user to receive the whisper.

response_codes.204: Successfully sent the whisper message or the message was silently dropped.
response_codes.400:
• The ID in the from_user_id and to_user_id query parameters must be different.
  • The message field must not contain an empty string.
  • The user that you're sending the whisper to doesn't allow whisper messages (see the Block Whispers from Strangers setting in your Security and Privacy settings).
  • Whisper messages may not be sent to suspended users.
  • The ID in the from_user_id query parameter is not valid.
  • The ID in the to_user_id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The user in the from_user_id query parameter must have a verified phone number.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:manage:whispers scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • This ID in from_user_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.403:
• Suspended users may not send whisper messages.
  • The account that's sending the message doesn't allow sending whispers.
response_codes.404: • The ID in to_user_id was not found.
response_codes.429: • The sending user exceeded the number of whisper requests that they may make. See Rate Limits for this endpoint above.

name: Delete Videos
description: Deletes one or more videos.
instruction: Deletes one or more videos. You may delete past broadcasts, highlights, or uploads.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:videos scope.

id.instruction:
The list of videos to delete. To specify more than one video, include the id parameter for each video to delete. For example, id=1234&id=5678. You can delete a maximum of 5 videos per request. Ignores invalid video IDs.

If the user doesn’t have permission to delete one of the videos in the list, none of the videos are deleted.

data.instruction: The list of IDs of the videos that were deleted.

response_codes.200: Successfully deleted the list of videos.
response_codes.400:
• The id query parameter is required.
  • The request exceeded the number of allowed id query parameters.
response_codes.401:
• The caller is not authorized to delete the specified video.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:manage:videos scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get Videos
description: Gets information about one or more published videos.
instruction: Gets information about one or more published videos. You may get videos by ID, by user, or by game/category. You may apply several filters to get a subset of the videos. The filters are applied as an AND operation to each video. For example, if language is set to ‘de’ and game_id is set to 21779, the response includes only videos that show playing League of Legends by users that stream in German. The filters apply only if you get videos by user ID or game ID.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

id.instruction:
A list of IDs that identify the videos you want to get. To get more than one video, include this parameter for each video you want to get. For example, id=1234&id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs. The endpoint ignores duplicate IDs and IDs that weren’t found (if there’s at least one valid ID).

The id, user_id, and game_id parameters are mutually exclusive.

user_id.instruction:
The ID of the user whose list of videos you want to get.

The id, user_id, and game_id parameters are mutually exclusive.

game_id.instruction:
A category or game ID. The response contains a maximum of 500 videos that show this content. To get category/game IDs, use the Search Categories endpoint.

The id, user_id, and game_id parameters are mutually exclusive.

language.instruction:
A filter used to filter the list of videos by the language that the video owner broadcasts in. For example, to get videos that were broadcast in German, set this parameter to the ISO 639-1 two-letter code for German (i.e., DE). For a list of supported languages, see Supported Stream Language. If the language is not supported, use “other.”

Specify this parameter only if you specify the game_id query parameter.

period.instruction:
A filter used to filter the list of videos by when they were published. For example, videos published in the last week. Possible values are:
  • all
  • day
  • month
  • week
The default is “all,” which returns videos published in all periods.

Specify this parameter only if you specify the game_id or user_id query parameter.

sort.instruction:
The order to sort the returned videos in. Possible values are:
  • time — Sort the results in descending order by when they were created (i.e., latest video first).
  • trending — Sort the results in descending order by biggest gains in viewership (i.e., highest trending video first).
  • views — Sort the results in descending order by most views (i.e., highest number of views first).
The default is “time.”

Specify this parameter only if you specify the game_id or user_id query parameter.

type.instruction:
A filter used to filter the list of videos by the video’s type. Possible case-sensitive values are:
  • all
  • archive — On-demand videos (VODs) of past streams.
  • highlight — Highlight reels of past streams.
  • upload — External videos that the broadcaster uploaded using the Video Producer.
The default is “all,” which returns all video types.

Specify this parameter only if you specify the game_id or user_id query parameter.

first.instruction:
The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

Specify this parameter only if you specify the game_id or user_id query parameter.

after.instruction:
The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

Specify this parameter only if you specify the user_id query parameter.

before.instruction:
The cursor used to get the previous page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

Specify this parameter only if you specify the user_id query parameter.

data.instruction: The list of published videos that match the filter criteria.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the video.

stream_id.instruction: The ID of the stream that the video originated from if the video’s type is “archive;” otherwise, null.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the video.

description.instruction: The video’s description.

created_at.instruction: The date and time, in UTC, of when the video was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

published_at.instruction: The date and time, in UTC, of when the video was published. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to a thumbnail image of the video. Before using the URL, you must replace the % and % placeholders with the width and height of the thumbnail you want returned. Specify the width and height in pixels. Because the CDN preserves the thumbnail’s ratio, the thumbnail may not be the exact size you requested.

viewable.instruction: The video’s viewable state. Always set to public.

view_count.instruction: The number of times that users have watched the video.

language.instruction: The ISO 639-1 two-letter language code that the video was broadcast in. For example, the language code is DE if the video was broadcast in German. For a list of supported languages, see Supported Stream Language. The language value is “other” if the video was broadcast in a language not in the list of supported languages.

type.instruction:
The video’s type. Possible values are:
  • archive — An on-demand video (VOD) of one of the broadcaster's past streams.
  • highlight — A highlight reel of one of the broadcaster's past streams. See Creating Highlights.
  • upload — A video that the broadcaster uploaded to their video library. See Upload under Video Producer.

duration.instruction: The video’s length in ISO 8601 duration format. For example, 3m21s represents 3 minutes, 21 seconds.

muted_segments.instruction: The segments that Twitch Audio Recognition muted; otherwise, null.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the video.

stream_id.instruction: The ID of the stream that the video originated from if the video’s type is “archive;” otherwise, null.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the video.

description.instruction: The video’s description.

created_at.instruction: The date and time, in UTC, of when the video was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

published_at.instruction: The date and time, in UTC, of when the video was published. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to a thumbnail image of the video. Before using the URL, you must replace the % and % placeholders with the width and height of the thumbnail you want returned. Specify the width and height in pixels. Because the CDN preserves the thumbnail’s ratio, the thumbnail may not be the exact size you requested.

viewable.instruction: The video’s viewable state. Always set to public.

view_count.instruction: The number of times that users have watched the video.

language.instruction: The ISO 639-1 two-letter language code that the video was broadcast in. For example, the language code is DE if the video was broadcast in German. For a list of supported languages, see Supported Stream Language. The language value is “other” if the video was broadcast in a language not in the list of supported languages.

type.instruction:
The video’s type. Possible values are:
  • archive — An on-demand video (VOD) of one of the broadcaster's past streams.
  • highlight — A highlight reel of one of the broadcaster's past streams. See Creating Highlights.
  • upload — A video that the broadcaster uploaded to their video library. See Upload under Video Producer.

duration.instruction: The duration of the muted segment, in seconds.

muted_segments.instruction: The segments that Twitch Audio Recognition muted; otherwise, null.

offset.instruction: The offset, in seconds, from the beginning of the video to where the muted segment begins.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the video.

stream_id.instruction: The ID of the stream that the video originated from if the video’s type is “archive;” otherwise, null.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the video.

description.instruction: The video’s description.

created_at.instruction: The date and time, in UTC, of when the video was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

published_at.instruction: The date and time, in UTC, of when the video was published. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to a thumbnail image of the video. Before using the URL, you must replace the % and % placeholders with the width and height of the thumbnail you want returned. Specify the width and height in pixels. Because the CDN preserves the thumbnail’s ratio, the thumbnail may not be the exact size you requested.

viewable.instruction: The video’s viewable state. Always set to public.

view_count.instruction: The number of times that users have watched the video.

language.instruction: The ISO 639-1 two-letter language code that the video was broadcast in. For example, the language code is DE if the video was broadcast in German. For a list of supported languages, see Supported Stream Language. The language value is “other” if the video was broadcast in a language not in the list of supported languages.

type.instruction:
The video’s type. Possible values are:
  • archive — An on-demand video (VOD) of one of the broadcaster's past streams.
  • highlight — A highlight reel of one of the broadcaster's past streams. See Creating Highlights.
  • upload — A video that the broadcaster uploaded to their video library. See Upload under Video Producer.

duration.instruction: The duration of the muted segment, in seconds.

muted_segments.instruction: The segments that Twitch Audio Recognition muted; otherwise, null.

offset.instruction: The offset, in seconds, from the beginning of the video to where the muted segment begins.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after or before query parameter depending on whether you’re paging forwards or backwards through the results.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of videos.
response_codes.400:
• The request must specify either the id or user_id or game_id query parameter.
  • The id, user_id, and game_id query parameters are mutually exclusive; you must specify only one of them.
  • The value in the id query parameter is not valid.
  • The ID in the game_id query parameter is not valid.
  • The value in the type query parameter is not valid.
  • The value in the period query parameter is not valid.
  • The value in the sort query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.404:
• The ID in the game_id query parameter was not found.
  • The ID in the id query parameter was not found. Returned only if all the IDs were not found; otherwise, the ID is ignored.

name: Update User Extensions
description: Updates an installed extension’s information.
instruction:
Updates an installed extension’s information. You can update the extension’s activation state, ID, and version number. The user ID in the access token identifies the broadcaster whose extensions you’re updating.
NOTE: If you try to activate an extension under multiple extension types, the last write wins (and there is no guarantee of write order).
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:edit:broadcast scope.

data.instruction:
The extensions to update. The data field is a dictionary of extension types. The dictionary’s possible keys are: panel, overlay, or component. The key’s value is a dictionary of extensions.

For the extension’s dictionary, the key is a sequential number beginning with 1. For panel and overlay extensions, the key’s value is an object that contains the following fields: active (true/false), id (the extension’s ID), and version (the extension’s version).

For component extensions, the key’s value includes the above fields plus the x and y fields, which identify the coordinate where the extension is placed.
The extensions that the broadcaster updated.

panel.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.
A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.

active.instruction: A Boolean value that determines the extension’s activation state. If false, the user has not configured a panel extension.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

overlay.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-overlay extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the overlay’s data for each key.

panel.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.

overlay.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-overlay extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the overlay’s data for each key.

active.instruction: A Boolean value that determines the extension’s activation state. If false, the user has not configured an overlay extension.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

component.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-component extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the component’s data for each key.

panel.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.

overlay.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-overlay extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the overlay’s data for each key.

component.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-component extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the component’s data for each key.

active.instruction: A Boolean value that determines the extension’s activation state. If false, the user has not configured a component extension.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

x.instruction: The x-coordinate where the extension is placed.

y.instruction: The y-coordinate where the extension is placed.

response_codes.200: Successfully updated the active extensions.
response_codes.400: • The JSON payload is malformed.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:edit:broadcast scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.404: • An extension with the specified id and version values was not found.

name: Get User Active Extensions
description: Gets the active extensions that the broadcaster has installed for each configuration.
instruction: Gets the active extensions that the broadcaster has installed for each configuration. NOTE: To include extensions that you have under development, you must specify a user access token that includes the user:read:broadcast or user:edit:broadcast scope.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

user_id.instruction:
The ID of the broadcaster whose active extensions you want to get.

This parameter is required if you specify an app access token and is optional if you specify a user access token. If you specify a user access token and don’t specify this parameter, the API uses the user ID from the access token.

data.instruction: The active extensions that the broadcaster has installed.

panel.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.
A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.

active.instruction: A Boolean value that determines the extension’s activation state. If false, the user has not configured this panel extension.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

overlay.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-overlay extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the overlay’s data for each key.

panel.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.

overlay.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-overlay extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the overlay’s data for each key.

active.instruction: A Boolean value that determines the extension’s activation state. If false, the user has not configured this overlay extension.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

component.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-component extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the component’s data for each key.

panel.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a panel extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the panel’s data for each key.

overlay.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-overlay extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the overlay’s data for each key.

component.instruction: A dictionary that contains the data for a video-component extension. The dictionary’s key is a sequential number beginning with 1. The following fields contain the component’s data for each key.

active.instruction: A Boolean value that determines the extension’s activation state. If false, the user has not configured this component extension.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

x.instruction: The x-coordinate where the extension is placed.

y.instruction: The y-coordinate where the extension is placed.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the user’s active extensions.
response_codes.400: • The user_id query parameter is required if you specify an app access token.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get User Extensions
description: Gets a list of all extensions (both active and inactive) that the broadcaster has installed.
instruction: Gets a list of all extensions (both active and inactive) that the broadcaster has installed. The user ID in the access token identifies the broadcaster.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:read:broadcast or user:edit:broadcast scope. To include inactive extensions, you must include the user:edit:broadcast scope.

data.instruction: The list of extensions that the user has installed.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension.

can_activate.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the extension is configured and can be activated. Is true if the extension is configured and can be activated.

type.instruction:
The extension types that you can activate for this extension. Possible values are:
  • component
  • mobile
  • overlay
  • panel

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the user’s installed extensions.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:read:broadcast scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Unblock User
description: Removes the user from the broadcaster’s list of blocked users.
instruction: Removes the user from the broadcaster’s list of blocked users. The user ID in the OAuth token identifies the broadcaster who’s removing the block.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:manage:blocked_users scope.

target_user_id.instruction: The ID of the user to remove from the broadcaster’s list of blocked users. The API ignores the request if the broadcaster hasn’t blocked the user.

response_codes.400: • The target_user_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:read:blocked_users scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Block User
description: Blocks the specified user from interacting with or having contact with the broadcaster.
instruction: Blocks the specified user from interacting with or having contact with the broadcaster. The user ID in the OAuth token identifies the broadcaster who is blocking the user. To learn more about blocking users, see Block Other Users on Twitch.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:manage:blocked_users scope.

target_user_id.instruction: The ID of the user to block. The API ignores the request if the broadcaster has already blocked the user.

source_context.instruction:
The location where the harassment took place that is causing the brodcaster to block the user. Possible values are:
  • chat
  • whisper
.

reason.instruction:
The reason that the broadcaster is blocking the user. Possible values are:
  • harassment
  • spam
  • other

response_codes.400:
• The target_user_id query parameter is required.
  • The ID in target_user_id cannot be the same as the user ID in the access token.
  • The value in source_context is not valid.
  • The value in reason is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:manage:blocked_users scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get User Block List
description: Gets the list of users that the broadcaster has blocked.
instruction: Gets the list of users that the broadcaster has blocked. Read More
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:read:blocked_users scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose list of blocked users you want to get.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of blocked users. The list is in descending order by when the user was blocked.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the blocked user.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of blocked users.
response_codes.400: • The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the request’s access token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:read:blocked_users scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get Users Follows
description: Gets information about users that are following other users.
instruction:
Gets information about users that are following other users. For example, you can use this endpoint to answer questions like “who is qotrok following,” “who is following qotrok,” or “is user X following user Y.”
Deprecation Notice: This endpoint is deprecated and will be decommissioned on August 3, 2023. Access to this endpoint is limited to client IDs that have called the endpoint on or before February 17, 2023.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

from_id.instruction:
A user ID. Specify this parameter to discover the users that this user is following.

You must specify this parameter, the to_id parameter, or both.

to_id.instruction:
A user ID. Specify this parameter to discover the users who are following this user.

You must specify this parameter, the from_id parameter, or both.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

total.instruction:
The number of items in the data field.
  • If the request includes only from_id, this is the total number of followed users.
  • If the request includes only to_id, this is the total number of followers.
  • If the request specifies both from_id and to_id, the total is 1 if the "from" user follows the "to" user; otherwise, the total is 0.

data.instruction: The list of follower-followee relationship information. The list is in descending order by when the follow occurred (most recent follow first).

from_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s following the user in to_id.

to_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s being followed by the user in from_id.

to_login.instruction: The login name of the user that’s being followed.

to_name.instruction: The display name of the user that’s being followed.

followed_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user in from_id began following the user in to_id.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

from_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s following the user in to_id.

to_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s being followed by the user in from_id.

to_login.instruction: The login name of the user that’s being followed.

to_name.instruction: The display name of the user that’s being followed.

followed_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user in from_id began following the user in to_id.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the follows information.
response_codes.400:
• The from_id query parameter, to_id query parameter, or both parameters are required.
  • The ID in the from_id query parameter is not valid
  • The ID in the to_id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Update User
description: Updates the user’s information.
instruction: Updates the specified user’s information. The user ID in the OAuth token identifies the user whose information you want to update. To include the user’s verified email address in the response, the user access token must also include the user:read:email scope.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:edit scope.

description.instruction:
The string to update the channel’s description to. The description is limited to a maximum of 300 characters.

To remove the description, specify this parameter but don’t set it’s value (for example, ?description=).

data.instruction: A list contains the single user that you updated.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the user.

type.instruction:
The type of user. Possible values are:
  • admin — Twitch administrator
  • global_mod
  • staff — Twitch staff
  • "" — Normal user

broadcaster_type.instruction:
The type of broadcaster. Possible values are:
  • affiliate — An affiliate broadcaster
  • partner — A partner broadcaster
  • "" — A normal broadcaster

description.instruction: The user’s description of their channel.

profile_image_url.instruction: A URL to the user’s profile image.

offline_image_url.instruction: A URL to the user’s offline image.

view_count.instruction:
The number of times the user’s channel has been viewed.

NOTE: This field has been deprecated (see Get Users API endpoint – “view_count” deprecation). Any data in this field is not valid and should not be used.

email.instruction:
The user’s verified email address. The object includes this field only if the user access token includes the user:read:email scope.

If the request contains more than one user, only the user associated with the access token that provided consent will include an email address — the email address for all other users will be empty.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time that the user’s account was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

response_codes.200: Successfully updated the specified user’s information.
response_codes.400: • The string in the description query parameter is too long.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:edit scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get Users
description: Gets information about one or more users.
instruction: Gets information about one or more users. You may look up users using their user ID, login name, or both but the sum total of the number of users you may look up is 100. For example, you may specify 50 IDs and 50 names or 100 IDs or names, but you cannot specify 100 IDs and 100 names. If you don’t specify IDs or login names, the request returns information about the user in the access token if you specify a user access token. To include the user’s verified email address in the response, you must use a user access token that includes the user:read:email scope.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

id.instruction: The ID of the user to get. To specify more than one user, include the id parameter for each user to get. For example, id=1234&id=5678. The maximum number of IDs you may specify is 100.

login.instruction: The login name of the user to get. To specify more than one user, include the login parameter for each user to get. For example, login=foo&login=bar. The maximum number of login names you may specify is 100.

data.instruction: The list of users.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the user.

type.instruction:
The type of user. Possible values are:
  • admin — Twitch administrator
  • global_mod
  • staff — Twitch staff
  • "" — Normal user

broadcaster_type.instruction:
The type of broadcaster. Possible values are:
  • affiliate — An affiliate broadcaster
  • partner — A partner broadcaster
  • "" — A normal broadcaster

description.instruction: The user’s description of their channel.

profile_image_url.instruction: A URL to the user’s profile image.

offline_image_url.instruction: A URL to the user’s offline image.

view_count.instruction:
The number of times the user’s channel has been viewed.

NOTE: This field has been deprecated (see Get Users API endpoint – “view_count” deprecation). Any data in this field is not valid and should not be used.

email.instruction:
The user’s verified email address. The object includes this field only if the user access token includes the user:read:email scope.

If the request contains more than one user, only the user associated with the access token that provided consent will include an email address — the email address for all other users will be empty.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time that the user’s account was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the specified users’ information.
response_codes.400:
• The id or login query parameter is required unless the request uses a user access token.
  • The request exceeded the maximum allowed number of id and/or login query parameters.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get Teams
description: Gets information about the specified Twitch team.
instruction: Gets information about the specified Twitch team. Read More
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

name.instruction: The name of the team to get. This parameter and the id parameter are mutually exclusive; you must specify the team’s name or ID but not both.

id.instruction: The ID of the team to get. This parameter and the name parameter are mutually exclusive; you must specify the team’s name or ID but not both.

data.instruction: A list that contains the single team that you requested.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the team member.

background_image_url.instruction: A URL to the team’s background image.

banner.instruction: A URL to the team’s banner.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the team was created.

updated_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of the last time the team was updated.

info.instruction: The team’s description. The description may contain formatting such as Markdown, HTML, newline (\n) characters, etc.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to a thumbnail image of the team’s logo.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the team.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the team’s information.
response_codes.400:
• The name or id query parameter is required.
  • Specify either the name or id query parameter but not both.
  • The ID in the id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.404: • The specified team was not found.

name: Get Channel Teams
description: Gets the list of Twitch teams that the broadcaster is a member of.
instruction: Gets the list of Twitch teams that the broadcaster is a member of.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose teams you want to get.

data.instruction: The list of teams that the broadcaster is a member of.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster.

background_image_url.instruction: A URL to the team’s background image.

banner.instruction: A URL to the team’s banner.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the team was created.

updated_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of the last time the team was updated.

info.instruction: The team’s description. The description may contain formatting such as Markdown, HTML, newline (\n) characters, etc.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to a thumbnail image of the team’s logo.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the team.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of teams.
response_codes.400: • The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.404:
• The broadcaster was not found.
  • The broadcaster is not a member of a team.

name: Get Stream Tags
description: Gets the list of stream tags that the broadcaster or Twitch added to their channel.
instruction: IMPORTANT Twitch is moving from Twitch-defined tags to channel-defined tags. IMPORTANT As of February 28, 2023, this endpoint returns an empty array. On July 13, 2023, it will return a 410 response. If you use this endpoint, please update your code to use Get Channel Information. Gets the list of stream tags that the broadcaster or Twitch added to their channel.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose stream tags you want to get.

data.instruction: The list of stream tags. The list is empty if the broadcaster or Twitch hasn’t added tags to the broadcaster’s channel.

tag_id.instruction: An ID that identifies this tag.

is_auto.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the tag is an automatic tag. An automatic tag is one that Twitch adds to the stream. Broadcasters may not add automatic tags to their channel. The value is true if the tag is an automatic tag; otherwise, false.

localization_names.instruction: A dictionary that contains the localized names of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<coutry/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized name.

localization_descriptions.instruction: A dictionary that contains the localized descriptions of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<coutry/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized description.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of tags.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id field is required.
  • The ID in the broadcaster_id field is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the access token.

name: Get All Stream Tags
description: Gets the list of all stream tags that Twitch defines. You can also filter the list by one or more tag IDs.
instruction: IMPORTANT Twitch is moving from Twitch-defined tags to channel-defined tags. IMPORTANT As of February 28, 2023, this endpoint returns an empty array. On July 13, 2023, it will return a 410 response. Gets a list of all stream tags that Twitch defines. The broadcaster may apply any of these to their channel except automatic tags. For an online list of the possible tags, see List of All Tags.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

tag_id.instruction: The ID of the tag to get. Used to filter the list of tags. To specify more than one tag, include the tag_id parameter for each tag to get. For example, tag_id=1234&tag_id=5678. The maximum number of IDs you may specify is 100. Ignores invalid IDs but not duplicate IDs.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of stream tags that the broadcaster can apply to their channel.

tag_id.instruction: An ID that identifies this tag.

is_auto.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the tag is an automatic tag. An automatic tag is one that Twitch adds to the stream. Broadcasters may not add automatic tags to their channel. The value is true if the tag is an automatic tag; otherwise, false.

localization_names.instruction: A dictionary that contains the localized names of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<country/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized name.

<code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">locali.instruction: A dictionary that contains the localized descriptions of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<country/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized description.

pagination.instruction: The information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

tag_id.instruction: An ID that identifies this tag.

is_auto.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the tag is an automatic tag. An automatic tag is one that Twitch adds to the stream. Broadcasters may not add automatic tags to their channel. The value is true if the tag is an automatic tag; otherwise, false.

localization_names.instruction: A dictionary that contains the localized names of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<country/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized name.

<code class=\"highlighter-rouge\">locali.instruction: A dictionary that contains the localized descriptions of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<country/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized description.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Set the request’s after query parameter to this value to page forwards through the results.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of tags.
response_codes.400:
• The tag_id query parameter is empty (for example, &tag_id=).
  • The list of tag IDs is too long.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the access token.

name: Check User Subscription
description: Checks whether the user subscribes to the broadcaster’s channel.
instruction: Checks whether the user subscribes to the broadcaster’s channel.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:read:subscriptions scope.A Twitch extensions may use an app access token if the broadcaster has granted the user:read:subscriptions scope from within the Twitch Extensions manager.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of a partner or affiliate broadcaster.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that you’re checking to see whether they subscribe to the broadcaster in broadcaster_id. This ID must match the user ID in the access Token.

data.instruction: A list that contains a single object with information about the user’s subscription.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster.

gifter_id.instruction: The ID of the user that gifted the subscription. The object includes this field only if is_gift is true.

gifter_login.instruction: The gifter’s login name. The object includes this field only if is_gift is true.

gifter_name.instruction: The gifter’s display name. The object includes this field only if is_gift is true.

is_gift.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the subscription is a gift subscription. Is true if the subscription was gifted.

tier.instruction:
The type of subscription. Possible values are:
  • 1000 — Tier 1
  • 2000 — Tier 2
  • 3000 — Tier 3

response_codes.200: The user subscribes to the broadcaster.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The user_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in user_id must match the user ID found in the request’s OAuth token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:read:subscriptions scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.404: • The user in user_id does not subscribe to the broadcaster in broadcaster_id.

name: Get Broadcaster Subscriptions
description: Gets a list of users that subscribe to the specified broadcaster.
instruction: Gets a list of users that subscribe to the specified broadcaster.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:subscriptions scope.A Twitch extensions may use an app access token if the broadcaster has granted the channel:read:subscriptions scope from within the Twitch Extensions manager.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The broadcaster’s ID. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

user_id.instruction: Filters the list to include only the specified subscribers. To specify more than one subscriber, include this parameter for each subscriber. For example, &user_id=1234&user_id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 100 subscribers.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Do not specify if you set the user_id query parameter. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

before.instruction: The cursor used to get the previous page of results. Do not specify if you set the user_id query parameter. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of users that subscribe to the broadcaster. The list is empty if the broadcaster has no subscribers.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster.

gifter_id.instruction: The ID of the user that gifted the subscription to the user. Is an empty string if is_gift is false.

gifter_login.instruction: The gifter’s login name. Is an empty string if is_gift is false.

gifter_name.instruction: The gifter’s display name. Is an empty string if is_gift is false.

is_gift.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the subscription is a gift subscription. Is true if the subscription was gifted.

tier.instruction:
The type of subscription. Possible values are:
  • 1000 — Tier 1
  • 2000 — Tier 2
  • 3000 — Tier 3

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the subscribing user.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster.

gifter_id.instruction: The ID of the user that gifted the subscription to the user. Is an empty string if is_gift is false.

gifter_login.instruction: The gifter’s login name. Is an empty string if is_gift is false.

gifter_name.instruction: The gifter’s display name. Is an empty string if is_gift is false.

is_gift.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the subscription is a gift subscription. Is true if the subscription was gifted.

tier.instruction:
The type of subscription. Possible values are:
  • 1000 — Tier 1
  • 2000 — Tier 2
  • 3000 — Tier 3

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the subscribing user.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next or previous page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after or before query parameter depending on whether you’re paging forwards or backwards.

points.instruction: The current number of subscriber points earned by this broadcaster. Points are based on the subscription tier of each user that subscribes to this broadcaster. For example, a Tier 1 subscription is worth 1 point, Tier 2 is worth 2 points, and Tier 3 is worth 6 points. The number of points determines the number of emote slots that are unlocked for the broadcaster (see Subscriber Emote Slots).

total.instruction: The total number of users that subscribe to this broadcaster.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of subscribers.
response_codes.400: • The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the request’s OAuth token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:read:subscriptions scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Get Stream Markers
description: Gets a list of markers from the user’s most recent stream or from the specified VOD/video.
instruction: Gets a list of markers from the user’s most recent stream or from the specified VOD/video. A marker is an arbitrary point in a live stream that the broadcaster or editor marked, so they can return to that spot later to create video highlights (see Video Producer, Highlights in the Twitch UX).
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:read:broadcast or channel:manage:broadcast scope.

user_id.instruction:
A user ID. The request returns the markers from this user’s most recent video. This ID must match the user ID in the access token or the user in the access token must be one of the broadcaster’s editors.

This parameter and the video_id query parameter are mutually exclusive.

video_id.instruction:
A video on demand (VOD)/video ID. The request returns the markers from this VOD/video. The user in the access token must own the video or the user must be one of the broadcaster’s editors.

This parameter and the user_id query parameter are mutually exclusive.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

before.instruction: The cursor used to get the previous page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of markers grouped by the user that created the marks.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that created the marker.

videos.instruction: A list of videos that contain markers. The list contains a single video.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that created the marker.

videos.instruction: A list of videos that contain markers. The list contains a single video.

video_id.instruction: An ID that identifies this video.

markers.instruction: The list of markers in this video. The list in ascending order by when the marker was created.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that created the marker.

videos.instruction: A list of videos that contain markers. The list contains a single video.

markers.instruction: The list of markers in this video. The list in ascending order by when the marker was created.

video_id.instruction: An ID that identifies this video.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this marker.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user created the marker.

description.instruction: The description that the user gave the marker to help them remember why they marked the location. Is an empty string if the user didn’t provide one.

position_seconds.instruction: The relative offset (in seconds) of the marker from the beginning of the stream.

url.instruction: A URL that opens the video in Twitch Highlighter.

pagination.instruction: The information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that created the marker.

videos.instruction: A list of videos that contain markers. The list contains a single video.

video_id.instruction: An ID that identifies this video.

markers.instruction: The list of markers in this video. The list in ascending order by when the marker was created.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this marker.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user created the marker.

description.instruction: The description that the user gave the marker to help them remember why they marked the location. Is an empty string if the user didn’t provide one.

position_seconds.instruction: The relative offset (in seconds) of the marker from the beginning of the stream.

url.instruction: A URL that opens the video in Twitch Highlighter.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Set the request’s after or before query parameter to this value depending on whether you’re paging forwards or backwards.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of markers.
response_codes.400: • The request must specify either the user_id or video_id query parameter, but not both.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:read:broadcast or user:manage:broadcast scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.403: • The user in the access token is not authorized to get the video's markers. The user in the access token must own the video or be one of the broadcaster's editors.
response_codes.404: • The user specified in the user_id query parameter doesn't have videos.

name: Create Stream Marker
description: Adds a marker to a live stream.
instruction:
Adds a marker to a live stream. A marker is an arbitrary point in a live stream that the broadcaster or editor wants to mark, so they can return to that spot later to create video highlights (see Video Producer, Highlights in the Twitch UX).
You may not add markers:
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:broadcast scope.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that’s streaming content. This ID must match the user ID in the access token or the user in the access token must be one of the broadcaster’s editors.

description.instruction: A short description of the marker to help the user remember why they marked the location. The maximum length of the description is 140 characters.

data.instruction: A list that contains the single marker that you added.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this marker.

created_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user created the marker.

position_seconds.instruction: The relative offset (in seconds) of the marker from the beginning of the stream.

description.instruction: A description that the user gave the marker to help them remember why they marked the location.

response_codes.200: Successfully created the marker.
response_codes.400:
• The user_id field is required.
  • The length of the string in the description field is too long.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the user:manage:broadcast scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.403: • The user in the access token is not authorized to create video markers for the user in the user_id field. The user in the access token must own the video or they must be one of the broadcaster's editors.
response_codes.404:
• The user in the user_id field is not streaming live.
  • The ID in the user_id field is not valid.
  • The user hasn't enabled video on demand (VOD).

name: Get Followed Streams
description: Gets the list of broadcasters that the user follows and that are streaming live.
instruction: Gets the list of broadcasters that the user follows and that are streaming live.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:read:follows scope.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user whose list of followed streams you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 100.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of live streams of broadcasters that the specified user follows. The list is in descending order by the number of viewers watching the stream. Because viewers come and go during a stream, it’s possible to find duplicate or missing streams in the list as you page through the results. The list is empty if none of the followed broadcasters are streaming live.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the stream. You can use this ID later to look up the video on demand (VOD).

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s broadcasting the stream.

game_id.instruction: The ID of the category or game being played.

game_name.instruction: The ID of the category or game being played.

type.instruction:
The type of stream. Possible values are:
  • live
If an error occurs, this field is set to an empty string.

title.instruction: The stream’s title. Is an empty string if not set.

viewer_count.instruction: The number of users watching the stream.

started_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast began.

language.instruction: The language that the stream uses. This is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code or other if the stream uses a language not in the list of supported stream languages.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to an image of a frame from the last 5 minutes of the stream. Replace the width and height placeholders in the URL (x) with the size of the image you want, in pixels.

tag_ids.instruction:
IMPORTANT As of February 28, 2023, this field is deprecated and returns only an empty array. If you use this field, please update your code to use the tags field.

The list of tags that apply to the stream. The list contains IDs only when the channel is steaming live. For a list of possible tags, see List of All Tags. The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the stream. You can use this ID later to look up the video on demand (VOD).

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s broadcasting the stream.

game_id.instruction: The ID of the category or game being played.

game_name.instruction: The ID of the category or game being played.

The type of stream. Possible values are:
  • live
If an error occurs, this field is set to an empty string.

viewer_count.instruction: The number of users watching the stream.

started_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast began.

language.instruction: The language that the stream uses. This is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code or other if the stream uses a language not in the list of supported stream languages.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to an image of a frame from the last 5 minutes of the stream. Replace the width and height placeholders in the URL (x) with the size of the image you want, in pixels.

tag_ids.instruction:
IMPORTANT As of February 28, 2023, this field is deprecated and returns only an empty array. If you use this field, please update your code to use the tags field.

The list of tags that apply to the stream. The list contains IDs only when the channel is steaming live. For a list of possible tags, see List of All Tags. The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

tags.instruction: The tags applied to the stream.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the stream. You can use this ID later to look up the video on demand (VOD).

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that’s broadcasting the stream.

game_id.instruction: The ID of the category or game being played.

game_name.instruction: The ID of the category or game being played.

type.instruction:
The type of stream. Possible values are:
  • live
If an error occurs, this field is set to an empty string.

title.instruction: The stream’s title. Is an empty string if not set.

viewer_count.instruction: The number of users watching the stream.

started_at.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast began.

language.instruction: The language that the stream uses. This is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code or other if the stream uses a language not in the list of supported stream languages.

thumbnail_url.instruction: A URL to an image of a frame from the last 5 minutes of the stream. Replace the width and height placeholders in the URL (x) with the size of the image you want, in pixels.

tag_ids.instruction:
IMPORTANT As of February 28, 2023, this field is deprecated and returns only an empty array. If you use this field, please update your code to use the tags field.

The list of tags that apply to the stream. The list contains IDs only when the channel is steaming live. For a list of possible tags, see List of All Tags. The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

tags.instruction: The tags applied to the stream.

is_mature.instruction: A Boolean value that indicates whether the stream is meant for mature audiences.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of broadcasters that the user follows and that are streaming live.

• The ID in user_id must match the user ID found in the access token.

name: Get Streams
description: Gets a list of all streams.
instruction: Gets a list of all streams. The list is in descending order by the number of viewers watching the stream. Because viewers come and go during a stream, it’s possible to find duplicate or missing streams in the list as you page through the results.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

user_id.instruction: A user ID used to filter the list of streams. Returns only the streams of those users that are broadcasting. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs. To specify multiple IDs, include the user_id parameter for each user. For example, &user_id=1234&user_id=5678.

user_login.instruction: A user login name used to filter the list of streams. Returns only the streams of those users that are broadcasting. You may specify a maximum of 100 login names. To specify multiple names, include the user_login parameter for each user. For example, &user_login=foo&user_login=bar.

game_id.instruction: A game (category) ID used to filter the list of streams. Returns only the streams that are broadcasting the game (category). You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs. To specify multiple IDs, include the game_id parameter for each game. For example, &game_id=9876&game_id=5432.

type.instruction:
The type of stream to filter the list of streams by. Possible values are:
  • all
  • live
The default is all.

language.instruction:
A language code used to filter the list of streams. Returns only streams that broadcast in the specified language. Specify the language using an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code or other if the broadcast uses a language not in the list of supported stream languages.

You may specify a maximum of 100 language codes. To specify multiple languages, include the language parameter for each language. For example, &language=de&language=fr.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

before.instruction: The cursor used to get the previous page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of streams.

name: Get Stream Key
description: Gets the channel’s stream key.
instruction: Gets the channel’s stream key.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:stream_key scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the channel. The ID must match the user ID in the access token.

data.instruction: A list that contains the channel’s stream key.

name: Search Channels
description: Gets the channels that match the specified query and have streamed content within the past 6 months.
instruction: Gets the channels that match the specified query and have streamed content within the past 6 months. The fields that the API uses for comparison depends on the value that the live_only query parameter is set to. If live_only is false, the API matches on the broadcaster’s login name. However, if live_only is true, the API matches on the broadcaster’s name and category name. To match, the beginning of the broadcaster’s name or category must match the query string. The comparison is case insensitive. If the query string is angel_of_death, it matches all names that begin with angel_of_death. However, if the query string is a phrase like angel of death, it matches to names starting with angelofdeath or names starting with angel_of_death. By default, the results include both live and offline channels. To get only live channels set the live_only query parameter to true.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

query.instruction: The URI-encoded search string. For example, encode search strings like angel of death as angel%20of%20death.

live_only.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the response includes only channels that are currently streaming live. Set to true to get only channels that are streaming live; otherwise, false to get live and offline channels. The default is false.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of channels that match the query. The list is empty if there are no matches.

broadcaster_language.instruction: The ISO 639-1 two-letter language code of the language used by the broadcaster. For example, en for English. If the broadcaster uses a language not in the list of supported stream languages, the value is other.

game_id.instruction: The ID of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played.

game_name.instruction: The name of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played.

id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the channel (this is the broadcaster’s ID).

is_live.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the broadcaster is streaming live. Is true if the broadcaster is streaming live; otherwise, false.

tag_ids.instruction:
IMPORTANT As of February 28, 2023, this field is deprecated and returns only an empty array. If you use this field, please update your code to use the tags field.

The list of tags that apply to the stream. The list contains IDs only when the channel is steaming live. For a list of possible tags, see List of All Tags. The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

title.instruction: The stream’s title. Is an empty string if the broadcaster didn’t set it.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of category names that matched the specified query string.
response_codes.400: • The query query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Search Categories
description: Gets the games or categories that match the specified query.
instruction: Gets the games or categories that match the specified query. To match, the category’s name must contain all parts of the query string. For example, if the query string is 42, the response includes any category name that contains 42 in the title. If the query string is a phrase like love computer, the response includes any category name that contains the words love and computer anywhere in the name. The comparison is case insensitive.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

query.instruction: The URI-encoded search string. For example, encode #archery as %23archery and search strings like angel of death as angel%20of%20death.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of games or categories that match the query. The list is empty if there are no matches.

box_art_url.instruction: A URL to an image of the game’s box art or streaming category.

name.instruction: The name of the game or category.

id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the game or category.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of category names that matched the specified query string.
response_codes.400: • The query query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

name: Delete Channel Stream Schedule Segment
description: Deletes a broadcast from the broadcaster’s streaming schedule.
instruction: Removes a broadcast segment from the broadcaster’s streaming schedule. NOTE: For recurring segments, removing a segment removes all segments in the recurring schedule.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:schedule scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the streaming schedule. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.instruction: The ID of the broadcast segment to remove.

response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
  • The id query parameter is required.
  • The ID in the id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the user access token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:manage:schedule scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID in the OAuth token.

name: Update Channel Stream Schedule Segment
description: Updates a scheduled broadcast segment.
instruction:
Updates a scheduled broadcast segment.
For recurring segments, updating a segment’s title, category, duration, and timezone, changes all segments in the recurring schedule, not just the specified segment.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:schedule scope.

start_time.instruction:
The date and time that the broadcast segment starts. Specify the date and time in RFC3339 format (for example, 2022-08-02T06:00:00Z).

NOTE: Only partners and affiliates may update a broadcast’s start time and only for non-recurring segments.

duration.instruction: The length of time, in minutes, that the broadcast is scheduled to run. The duration must be in the range 30 through 1380 (23 hours).

category_id.instruction: The ID of the category that best represents the broadcast’s content. To get the category ID, use the Search Categories endpoint.

title.instruction: The broadcast’s title. The title may contain a maximum of 140 characters.

is_canceled.instruction:
A Boolean value that indicates whether the broadcast is canceled. Set to true to cancel the segment.

NOTE: For recurring segments, the API cancels the first segment after the current UTC date and time and not the specified segment (unless the specified segment is the next segment after the current UTC date and time).

timezone.instruction: The time zone where the broadcast takes place. Specify the time zone using IANA time zone database format (for example, America/New_York).

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster who owns the broadcast segment to update. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

id.instruction: The ID of the broadcast segment to update.

data.instruction: The broadcaster’s streaming scheduled.

segments.instruction: A list that contains the single broadcast segment that you updated.
A list that contains the single broadcast segment that you updated.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this broadcast segment.

start_time.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast starts.

end_time.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast ends.

canceled_until.instruction: Indicates whether the broadcaster canceled this segment of a recurring broadcast. If the broadcaster canceled this segment, this field is set to the same value that’s in the end_time field; otherwise, it’s set to null.

category.instruction: The type of content that the broadcaster plans to stream or null if not specified.

segments.instruction: A list that contains the single broadcast segment that you updated.

category.instruction: The type of content that the broadcaster plans to stream or null if not specified.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the category that best represents the content that the broadcaster plans to stream. For example, the game’s ID if the broadcaster will play a game or the Just Chatting ID if the broadcaster will host a talk show.

start_time.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast starts.

end_time.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast ends.

canceled_until.instruction: Indicates whether the broadcaster canceled this segment of a recurring broadcast. If the broadcaster canceled this segment, this field is set to the same value that’s in the end_time field; otherwise, it’s set to null.

name.instruction: The name of the category. For example, the game’s title if the broadcaster will play a game or Just Chatting if the broadcaster will host a talk show.

is_recurring.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the broadcast is part of a recurring series that streams at the same time each week or is a one-time broadcast. Is true if the broadcast is part of a recurring series.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the broadcast schedule.

vacation.instruction: The dates when the broadcaster is on vacation and not streaming. Is set to null if vacation mode is not enabled.

• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
