The sizes that the emote is available in. For example, if the emote is available in small and medium sizes, the array contains 1.0 and 2.0. Possible sizes are:
  • 1.0 — A small version (28px x 28px) is available.
  • 2.0 — A medium version (56px x 56px) is available.
  • 3.0 — A large version (112px x 112px) is available.

theme_mode.instruction:
The background themes that the emote is available in. Possible themes are:
  • dark
  • light

template.instruction: A templated URL. Use the values from the id, format, scale, and theme_mode fields to replace the like-named placeholder strings in the templated URL to create a CDN (content delivery network) URL that you use to fetch the emote. For information about what the template looks like and how to use it to fetch emotes, see Emote CDN URL format. You should use this template instead of using the URLs in the images object.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the emotes for the specified emote sets.
response_codes.400:
• The emote_set_id query parameter is required.
  • The number of emote_set_id query parameters exceeds the maximum allowed.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a valid app access token or user access token.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.

name: Get Channel Emotes
description: Gets the broadcaster’s list of custom emotes.
instruction: Gets the broadcaster’s list of custom emotes. Broadcasters create these custom emotes for users who subscribe to or follow the channel or cheer Bits in the channel’s chat window. Learn More For information about the custom emotes, see subscriber emotes, Bits tier emotes, and follower emotes. NOTE: With the exception of custom follower emotes, users may use custom emotes in any Twitch chat.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster whose emotes you want to get.

data.instruction: The list of emotes that the specified broadcaster created. If the broadcaster hasn’t created custom emotes, the list is empty.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this emote.

name.instruction: The name of the emote. This is the name that viewers type in the chat window to get the emote to appear.

images.instruction:
The image URLs for the emote. These image URLs always provide a static, non-animated emote image with a light background.

NOTE: You should use the templated URL in the template field to fetch the image instead of using these URLs.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this emote.

name.instruction: The name of the emote. This is the name that viewers type in the chat window to get the emote to appear.

images.instruction:
The image URLs for the emote. These image URLs always provide a static, non-animated emote image with a light background.

NOTE: You should use the templated URL in the template field to fetch the image instead of using these URLs.

url_1x.instruction: A URL to the small version (28px x 28px) of the emote.

url_2x.instruction: A URL to the medium version (56px x 56px) of the emote.

url_4x.instruction: A URL to the large version (112px x 112px) of the emote.

tier.instruction: The subscriber tier at which the emote is unlocked. This field contains the tier information only if emote_type is set to subscriptions, otherwise, it’s an empty string.

emote_type.instruction:
The type of emote. The possible values are:
  • bitstier — A custom Bits tier emote.
  • follower — A custom follower emote.
  • subscriptions — A custom subscriber emote.

emote_set_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the emote set that the emote belongs to.

format.instruction:
The formats that the emote is available in. For example, if the emote is available only as a static PNG, the array contains only static. But if the emote is available as a static PNG and an animated GIF, the array contains static and animated. The possible formats are:
  • animated — An animated GIF is available for this emote.
  • static — A static PNG file is available for this emote.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this emote.

name.instruction: The name of the emote. This is the name that viewers type in the chat window to get the emote to appear.

images.instruction:
The image URLs for the emote. These image URLs always provide a static, non-animated emote image with a light background.

NOTE: You should use the templated URL in the template field to fetch the image instead of using these URLs.

url_1x.instruction: A URL to the small version (28px x 28px) of the emote.

url_2x.instruction: A URL to the medium version (56px x 56px) of the emote.

url_4x.instruction: A URL to the large version (112px x 112px) of the emote.

tier.instruction: The subscriber tier at which the emote is unlocked. This field contains the tier information only if emote_type is set to subscriptions, otherwise, it’s an empty string.

emote_type.instruction:
The type of emote. The possible values are:
  • bitstier — A custom Bits tier emote.
  • follower — A custom follower emote.
  • subscriptions — A custom subscriber emote.

emote_set_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the emote set that the emote belongs to.

format.instruction:
The formats that the emote is available in. For example, if the emote is available only as a static PNG, the array contains only static. But if the emote is available as a static PNG and an animated GIF, the array contains static and animated. The possible formats are:
  • animated — An animated GIF is available for this emote.
  • static — A static PNG file is available for this emote.

scale.instruction:
The sizes that the emote is available in. For example, if the emote is available in small and medium sizes, the array contains 1.0 and 2.0. Possible sizes are:
  • 1.0 — A small version (28px x 28px) is available.
  • 2.0 — A medium version (56px x 56px) is available.
  • 3.0 — A large version (112px x 112px) is available.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies this emote.

name.instruction: The name of the emote. This is the name that viewers type in the chat window to get the emote to appear.

images.instruction:

NOTE: You should use the templated URL in the template field to fetch the image instead of using these URLs.

  • static — A static PNG file is available for this emote.

url_2x.instruction: A URL to the medium version (56px x 56px) of the emote.

url_4x.instruction: A URL to the large version (112px x 112px) of the emote.

tier.instruction: The subscriber tier at which the emote is unlocked. This field contains the tier information only if emote_type is set to subscriptions, otherwise, it’s an empty string.

emote_type.instruction:
The type of emote. The possible values are:
  • bitstier — A custom Bits tier emote.
  • follower — A custom follower emote.
  • subscriptions — A custom subscriber emote.

emote_set_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the emote set that the emote belongs to.

scale.instruction:
The sizes that the emote is available in. For example, if the emote is available in small and medium sizes, the array contains 1.0 and 2.0. Possible sizes are:
  • 1.0 — A small version (28px x 28px) is available.
  • 2.0 — A medium version (56px x 56px) is available.
  • 3.0 — A large version (112px x 112px) is available.

theme_mode.instruction:
The background themes that the emote is available in. Possible themes are:
  • dark
  • light

template.instruction: A templated URL. Use the values from the id, format, scale, and theme_mode fields to replace the like-named placeholder strings in the templated URL to create a CDN (content delivery network) URL that you use to fetch the emote. For information about what the template looks like and how to use it to fetch emotes, see Emote CDN URL format. You should use this template instead of using the URLs in the images object.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved broadcaster’s list of custom emotes.
response_codes.400: • The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a valid app access token or user access token.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.

name: Get Chatters
description: Gets the list of users that are connected to the broadcaster’s chat session.
instruction: Gets the list of users that are connected to the broadcaster’s chat session. NOTE: There is a delay between when users join and leave a chat and when the list is updated accordingly. To determine whether a user is a moderator or VIP, use the Get Moderators and Get VIPs endpoints. You can check the roles of up to 100 users.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the moderator:read:chatters scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose list of chatters you want to get.

moderator_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster or one of the broadcaster’s moderators. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 1,000. The default is 100.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of users that are connected to the broadcaster’s chat room. The list is empty if no users are connected to the chat room.

user_id.instruction: The ID of a user that’s connected to the broadcaster’s chat room.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

user_id.instruction: The ID of a user that’s connected to the broadcaster’s chat room.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

total.instruction: The total number of users that are connected to the broadcaster’s chat room. As you page through the list, the number of users may change as users join and leave the chat room.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of chatters.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
  • The moderator_id query parameter is required.
  • The ID in the moderator_id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in the moderator_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the moderator:read:chatters scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.403: • The user in the moderator_id query parameter is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

name: Get Charity Campaign Donations
description: Gets the list of donations that users have made to the broadcaster’s active charity campaign.
instruction: Gets the list of donations that users have made to the broadcaster’s active charity campaign. To receive events as donations occur, subscribe to the channel.charity_campaign.donate subscription type.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:charity scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that’s currently running a charity campaign. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: A list that contains the donations that users have made to the broadcaster’s charity campaign. The list is empty if the broadcaster is not currently running a charity campaign; the donation information is not available after the campaign ends.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the donation. The ID is unique across campaigns.

campaign_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the charity campaign that the donation applies to.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies a user that donated money to the campaign.

amount.instruction: An object that contains the amount of money that the user donated.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the donation. The ID is unique across campaigns.

campaign_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the charity campaign that the donation applies to.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies a user that donated money to the campaign.

amount.instruction: An object that contains the amount of money that the user donated.

value.instruction: The monetary amount. The amount is specified in the currency’s minor unit. For example, the minor units for USD is cents, so if the amount is $5.50 USD, value is set to 550.

decimal_places.instruction:
The number of decimal places used by the currency. For example, USD uses two decimal places. Use this number to translate value from minor units to major units by using the formula:

value / 10^decimal_places

currency.instruction: The ISO-4217 three-letter currency code that identifies the type of currency in value.

pagination.instruction: An object that contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the donation. The ID is unique across campaigns.

campaign_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the charity campaign that the donation applies to.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies a user that donated money to the campaign.

amount.instruction: An object that contains the amount of money that the user donated.

value.instruction: The monetary amount. The amount is specified in the currency’s minor unit. For example, the minor units for USD is cents, so if the amount is $5.50 USD, value is set to 550.

decimal_places.instruction:
The number of decimal places used by the currency. For example, USD uses two decimal places. Use this number to translate value from minor units to major units by using the formula:

value / 10^decimal_places

currency.instruction: The ISO-4217 three-letter currency code that identifies the type of currency in value.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of donations that users contributed to the broadcaster’s charity campaign.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:read:charity scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header must match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.403: • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.

name: Get Charity Campaign
description: Gets information about the broadcaster’s active charity campaign.
instruction: Gets information about the charity campaign that a broadcaster is running. For example, the campaign’s fundraising goal and the current amount of donations. To receive events when progress is made towards the campaign’s goal or the broadcaster changes the fundraising goal, subscribe to the channel.charity_campaign.progress subscription type.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:charity scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that’s currently running a charity campaign. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

data.instruction: A list that contains the charity campaign that the broadcaster is currently running. The list is empty if the broadcaster is not running a charity campaign; the campaign information is not available after the campaign ends.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the charity campaign.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that’s running the campaign.

charity_logo.instruction: A URL to an image of the charity’s logo. The image’s type is PNG and its size is 100px X 100px.

charity_website.instruction: A URL to the charity’s website.

current_amount.instruction: The current amount of donations that the campaign has received.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the charity campaign.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that’s running the campaign.

charity_logo.instruction: A URL to an image of the charity’s logo. The image’s type is PNG and its size is 100px X 100px.

charity_website.instruction: A URL to the charity’s website.

current_amount.instruction: The current amount of donations that the campaign has received.

value.instruction: The monetary amount. The amount is specified in the currency’s minor unit. For example, the minor units for USD is cents, so if the amount is $5.50 USD, value is set to 550.

decimal_places.instruction:
The number of decimal places used by the currency. For example, USD uses two decimal places. Use this number to translate value from minor units to major units by using the formula:

value / 10^decimal_places

currency.instruction: The ISO-4217 three-letter currency code that identifies the type of currency in value.

target_amount.instruction: The campaign’s fundraising goal. This field is null if the broadcaster has not defined a fundraising goal.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the charity campaign.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that’s running the campaign.

charity_logo.instruction: A URL to an image of the charity’s logo. The image’s type is PNG and its size is 100px X 100px.

charity_website.instruction: A URL to the charity’s website.

current_amount.instruction: The current amount of donations that the campaign has received.

target_amount.instruction: The campaign’s fundraising goal. This field is null if the broadcaster has not defined a fundraising goal.

value.instruction: The monetary amount. The amount is specified in the currency’s minor unit. For example, the minor units for USD is cents, so if the amount is $5.50 USD, value is set to 550.

decimal_places.instruction:
The number of decimal places used by the currency. For example, USD uses two decimal places. Use this number to translate value from minor units to major units by using the formula:

value / 10^decimal_places

currency.instruction: The ISO-4217 three-letter currency code that identifies the type of currency in value.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved information about the broadcaster’s active charity campaign.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:read:charity scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header must match the client ID specified in the access token.
response_codes.403: • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.

name: Update Redemption Status
description: Updates a redemption’s status.
instruction: Updates a redemption’s status. You may update a redemption only if its status is UNFULFILLED. The app used to create the reward is the only app that may update the redemption.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:redemptions scope.

status.instruction:
The status to set the redemption to. Possible values are:
  • CANCELED
  • FULFILLED
Setting the status to CANCELED refunds the user’s channel points.

id.instruction: A list of IDs that identify the redemptions to update. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each redemption you want to update. For example, id=1234&id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 50 IDs.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that’s updating the redemption. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

reward_id.instruction: The ID that identifies the reward that’s been redeemed.

data.instruction: The list contains the single redemption that you updated.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies this redemption..

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that redeemed the reward.

reward.instruction: An object that describes the reward that the user redeemed.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the reward.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that redeemed the reward.

reward.instruction: An object that describes the reward that the user redeemed.

prompt.instruction: The prompt displayed to the viewer if user input is required.

cost.instruction: The reward’s cost, in Channel Points.

user_input.instruction: The text that the user entered at the prompt when they redeemed the reward; otherwise, an empty string if user input was not required.

status.instruction:
The state of the redemption. Possible values are:
  • CANCELED
  • FULFILLED
  • UNFULFILLED

redeemed_at.instruction: The date and time of when the reward was redeemed, in RFC3339 format.

response_codes.200: Successfully updated the redemption’s status.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The reward_id query parameter is required.
  • The id query parameter is required.
  • The value in the status query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:manage:redemptions scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.403:
• The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID used to create the custom reward.
  • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.
response_codes.404:
• The custom reward specified in the reward_id query parameter was not found.
  • The redemptions specified using the id query parameter were not found or their statuses weren't marked as UNFULFILLED.

name: Update Custom Reward
description: Updates a custom reward.
instruction: Updates a custom reward. The app used to create the reward is the only app that may update the reward.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:redemptions scope.

request_body.text: The body of the request should contain only the fields you’re updating.

title.instruction: The reward’s title. The title may contain a maximum of 45 characters and it must be unique amongst all of the broadcaster’s custom rewards.

prompt.instruction: The prompt shown to the viewer when they redeem the reward. Specify a prompt if is_user_input_required is true. The prompt is limited to a maximum of 200 characters.

cost.instruction: The cost of the reward, in channel points. The minimum is 1 point.

background_color.instruction: The background color to use for the reward. Specify the color using Hex format (for example, #00E5CB).

is_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that indicates whether the reward is enabled. Set to true to enable the reward. Viewers see only enabled rewards.

is_user_input_required.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether users must enter information to redeem the reward. Set to true if user input is required. See the prompt field.

is_max_per_stream_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to limit the maximum number of redemptions allowed per live stream (see the max_per_stream field). Set to true to limit redemptions.

max_per_stream.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions allowed per live stream. Applied only if is_max_per_stream_enabled is true. The minimum value is 1.

is_max_per_user_per_stream_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to limit the maximum number of redemptions allowed per user per stream (see max_per_user_per_stream). The minimum value is 1. Set to true to limit redemptions.

max_per_user_per_stream.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions allowed per user per stream. Applied only if is_max_per_user_per_stream_enabled is true.

is_global_cooldown_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to apply a cooldown period between redemptions. Set to true to apply a cooldown period. For the duration of the cooldown period, see global_cooldown_seconds.

global_cooldown_seconds.instruction: The cooldown period, in seconds. Applied only if is_global_cooldown_enabled is true. The minimum value is 1; however, for it to be shown in the Twitch UX, the minimum value is 60.

is_paused.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to pause the reward. Set to true to pause the reward. Viewers can’t redeem paused rewards..

should_redemptions_skip_request_queue.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether redemptions should be set to FULFILLED status immediately when a reward is redeemed. If false, status is set to UNFULFILLED and follows the normal request queue process.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that’s updating the reward. This ID must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.

id.instruction: The ID of the reward to update.

data.instruction: The list contains the single reward that you updated.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies this custom reward.

prompt.instruction: The prompt shown to the viewer when they redeem the reward if user input is required. See the is_user_input_required field.

cost.instruction: The cost of the reward in Channel Points.

image.instruction: A set of custom images for the reward. This field is null if the broadcaster didn’t upload images.

is_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the reward is enabled. Is true if enabled; otherwise, false. Disabled rewards aren’t shown to the user.

max_per_stream_setting.instruction: The settings used to determine whether to apply a maximum to the number of redemptions allowed per live stream.

url_2x.instruction: The URL to a medium version of the image.

url_4x.instruction: The URL to a large version of the image.

background_color.instruction: The background color to use for the reward. The color is in Hex format (for example, #00E5CB).

is_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to apply a cooldown period. Is true if a cooldown period is enabled.

is_user_input_required.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the user must enter information when they redeem the reward. Is true if the user is prompted.

max_per_stream.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions allowed per live stream.

max_per_user_per_stream.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions allowed per user per live stream.

is_paused.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the reward is currently paused. Is true if the reward is paused. Viewers can’t redeem paused rewards.

is_in_stock.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the reward is currently in stock. Is true if the reward is in stock. Viewers can’t redeem out of stock rewards.

should_redemptions_skip_request_queue.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether redemptions should be set to FULFILLED status immediately when a reward is redeemed. If false, status is set to UNFULFILLED and follows the normal request queue process.

redemptions_redeemed_current_stream.instruction: The number of redemptions redeemed during the current live stream. The number counts against the max_per_stream_setting limit. This field is null if the broadcaster’s stream isn’t live or max_per_stream_setting isn’t enabled.

cooldown_expires_at.instruction: The timestamp of when the cooldown period expires. Is null if the reward isn’t in a cooldown state. See the global_cooldown_setting field.

response_codes.200: Successfully updated the custom reward.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The id query parameter is required.
  • The title must contain a minimum of 1 character and a maximum of 45 characters.
  • The title must be unique amongst all of the broadcaster's custom rewards.
  • The cost field must contain a minimum of 1 point.
  • The prompt field is limited to a maximum of 200 characters.
  • If is_max_per_stream_enabled is true, the minimum value for max_per_stream is 1.
  • If is_max_per_user_per_stream_enabled is true, the minimum value for max_per_user_per_stream is 1.
  • If is_global_cooldown_enabled is true, the minimum value for global_cooldown_seconds is 1 and the maximum is 604800.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:manage:redemptions scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valide.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.403:
• The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID used to create the custom reward.
  • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.
response_codes.404: • The custom reward specified in the id query parameter was not found.

name: Get Custom Reward Redemption
description: Gets a list of redemptions for a custom reward.
instruction: Gets a list of redemptions for the specified custom reward. The app used to create the reward is the only app that may get the redemptions.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:redemptions or channel:manage:redemptions scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the custom reward. This ID must match the user ID found in the user OAuth token.

reward_id.instruction: The ID that identifies the custom reward whose redemptions you want to get.

status.instruction:
The status of the redemptions to return. The possible case-sensitive values are:
  • CANCELED
  • FULFILLED
  • UNFULFILLED
NOTE: This field is required only if you don’t specify the id query parameter.

NOTE: Canceled and fulfilled redemptions are returned for only a few days after they’re canceled or fulfilled.

id.instruction:
A list of IDs to filter the redemptions by. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each redemption you want to get. For example, id=1234&id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 50 IDs.

Duplicate IDs are ignored. The response contains only the IDs that were found. If none of the IDs were found, the response is 404 Not Found.

sort.instruction:
The order to sort redemptions by. The possible case-sensitive values are:
  • OLDEST
  • NEWEST
The default is OLDEST.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read more

first.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 redemption per page and the maximum is 50. The default is 20.

data.instruction: The list of redemptions for the specified reward. The list is empty if there are no redemptions that match the redemption criteria.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies this redemption.

user_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the user that redeemed the reward.

user_input.instruction: The text the user entered at the prompt when they redeemed the reward; otherwise, an empty string if user input was not required.

status.instruction:
The state of the redemption. Possible values are:
  • CANCELED
  • FULFILLED
  • UNFULFILLED

redeemed_at.instruction: The date and time of when the reward was redeemed, in RFC3339 format.

reward.instruction: The reward that the user redeemed.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the redeemed reward.

user_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the user that redeemed the reward.

user_input.instruction: The text the user entered at the prompt when they redeemed the reward; otherwise, an empty string if user input was not required.

status.instruction:
The state of the redemption. Possible values are:
  • CANCELED
  • FULFILLED
  • UNFULFILLED

redeemed_at.instruction: The date and time of when the reward was redeemed, in RFC3339 format.

reward.instruction: The reward that the user redeemed.

prompt.instruction: The prompt displayed to the viewer if user input is required.

cost.instruction: The reward’s cost, in Channel Points.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of redeemed custom rewards.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The reward_id query parameter is required.
  • The status query parameter is required if you didn't specify the id query parameter.
  • The value in the status query parameter is not valid.
  • The value in the sort query parameter is not valid.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:read:redemptions scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.403:
• The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID used to create the custom reward.
  • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.
response_codes.404: • All of the redemptions specified using the id query parameter were not found.

name: Get Custom Reward
description: Gets a list of custom rewards that the specified broadcaster created.
instruction: Gets a list of custom rewards that the specified broadcaster created. NOTE: A channel may offer a maximum of 50 rewards, which includes both enabled and disabled rewards.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:redemptions or channel:manage:redemptions scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose custom rewards you want to get. This ID must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.

id.instruction:
A list of IDs to filter the rewards by. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each reward you want to get. For example, id=1234&id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 50 IDs.

Duplicate IDs are ignored. The response contains only the IDs that were found. If none of the IDs were found, the response is 404 Not Found.

only_manageable_rewards.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the response contains only the custom rewards that the app may manage (the app is identified by the ID in the Client-Id header). Set to true to get only the custom rewards that the app may manage. The default is false.

data.instruction: A list of custom rewards. The list is in ascending order by id. If the broadcaster hasn’t created custom rewards, the list is empty.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies this custom reward.

prompt.instruction: The prompt shown to the viewer when they redeem the reward if user input is required (see the is_user_input_required field).

cost.instruction: The cost of the reward in Channel Points.

image.instruction: A set of custom images for the reward. This field is null if the broadcaster didn’t upload images.

name: Delete Custom Reward
description: Deletes a custom reward that the broadcaster created.
instruction:
Deletes a custom reward that the broadcaster created.
The app used to create the reward is the only app that may delete it. If the reward’s redemption status is UNFULFILLED at the time the reward is deleted, its redemption status is marked as FULFILLED.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:redemptions scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that created the custom reward. This ID must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.

id.instruction: The ID of the custom reward to delete.

response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:manage:redemptions scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.403:
• The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID used to create the custom reward.
  • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.
response_codes.404: • The custom reward specified in the id query parameter was not found.

name: Create Custom Rewards
description: Creates a Custom Reward in the broadcaster’s channel.
instruction: Creates a Custom Reward in the broadcaster’s channel. The maximum number of custom rewards per channel is 50, which includes both enabled and disabled rewards.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:redemptions scope.

title.instruction: The custom reward’s title. The title may contain a maximum of 45 characters and it must be unique amongst all of the broadcaster’s custom rewards.

cost.instruction: The cost of the reward, in Channel Points. The minimum is 1 point.

prompt.instruction: The prompt shown to the viewer when they redeem the reward. Specify a prompt if is_user_input_required is true. The prompt is limited to a maximum of 200 characters.

is_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the reward is enabled. Viewers see only enabled rewards. The default is true.

background_color.instruction: The background color to use for the reward. Specify the color using Hex format (for example, #9147FF).

is_user_input_required.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether the user needs to enter information when redeeming the reward. See the prompt field. The default is false.

is_max_per_stream_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to limit the maximum number of redemptions allowed per live stream (see the max_per_stream field). The default is false.

max_per_stream.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions allowed per live stream. Applied only if is_max_per_stream_enabled is true. The minimum value is 1.

is_max_per_user_per_stream_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to limit the maximum number of redemptions allowed per user per stream (see the max_per_user_per_stream field). The default is false.

max_per_user_per_stream.instruction: The maximum number of redemptions allowed per user per stream. Applied only if is_max_per_user_per_stream_enabled is true. The minimum value is 1.

is_global_cooldown_enabled.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether to apply a cooldown period between redemptions (see the global_cooldown_seconds field for the duration of the cooldown period). The default is false.

global_cooldown_seconds.instruction: The cooldown period, in seconds. Applied only if the is_global_cooldown_enabled field is true. The minimum value is 1; however, the minimum value is 60 for it to be shown in the Twitch UX.

should_redemptions_skip_request_queue.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether redemptions should be set to FULFILLED status immediately when a reward is redeemed. If false, status is set to UNFULFILLED and follows the normal request queue process. The default is false.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster to add the custom reward to. This ID must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.

data.instruction: A list that contains the single custom reward you created.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

id.instruction: The ID that uniquely identifies this custom reward.

prompt.instruction: The prompt shown to the viewer when they redeem the reward if user input is required (see the is_user_input_required field).

cost.instruction: The cost of the reward in Channel Points.

image.instruction: A set of custom images for the reward. This field is set to null if the broadcaster didn’t upload images.

  • If is_max_per_user_per_stream_enabled is true, the minimum value for max_per_user_per_stream is 1.
  • If is_global_cooldown_enabled is true, the minimum value for global_cooldown_seconds is 1.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The user access token is missing the channel:manage:redemptions scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.403: • The broadcaster is not a partner or affiliate.

name: Get Channel Followers
description: Gets a list of users that follow the specified broadcaster. You can also use this endpoint to see whether a specific user follows the broadcaster.
instruction: Gets a list of users that follow the specified broadcaster. You can also use this endpoint to see whether a specific user follows the broadcaster.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the moderator:read:followers scope. The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token or the user must be a moderator for the specified broadcaster. If a scope is not provided, only the total follower count will be included in the response.

user_id.instruction: A user’s ID. Use this parameter to see whether the user follows this broadcaster. If specified, the response contains this user if they follow the broadcaster. If not specified, the response contains all users that follow the broadcaster.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The broadcaster’s ID. Returns the list of users that follow this broadcaster.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read more.

data.instruction: The list of users that follow the specified broadcaster. The list is in descending order by followed_at (with the most recent follower first). The list is empty if nobody follows the broadcaster.

followed_at.instruction: The UTC timestamp when the user started following the broadcaster.

user_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the user that’s following the broadcaster.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read more.

followed_at.instruction: The UTC timestamp when the user started following the broadcaster.

user_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the user that’s following the broadcaster.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

total.instruction: The total number of users that follow this broadcaster. As someone pages through the list, the number of users may change as users follow or unfollow the broadcaster.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of followers.
response_codes.400:
Possible reasons:
  • The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
  • The user_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
Possible reasons:
  • The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token or the user must be a moderator for the specified broadcaster.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token is missing the moderator:read:followers scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.

name: Get Followed Channels
description: Gets a list of broadcasters that the specified user follows. You can also use this endpoint to see whether a user follows a specific broadcaster.
instruction: Gets a list of broadcasters that the specified user follows. You can also use this endpoint to see whether a user follows a specific broadcaster.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the user:read:follows scope.

user_id.instruction: A user’s ID. Returns the list of broadcasters that this user follows. This ID must match the user ID in the user OAuth token.

broadcaster_id.instruction: A broadcaster’s ID. Use this parameter to see whether the user follows this broadcaster. If specified, the response contains this broadcaster if the user follows them. If not specified, the response contains all broadcasters that the user follows.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read more.

data.instruction: The list of broadcasters that the user follows. The list is in descending order by followed_at (with the most recently followed broadcaster first). The list is empty if the user doesn’t follow anyone.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster that this user is following.

followed_at.instruction: The UTC timestamp when the user started following the broadcaster.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read more.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster that this user is following.

followed_at.instruction: The UTC timestamp when the user started following the broadcaster.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

total.instruction: The total number of broadcasters that the user follows. As someone pages through the list, the number may change as the user follows or unfollows broadcasters.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of followers.
response_codes.400:
Possible reasons:
  • The user_id query parameter is required.
  • The broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
  • The user_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
Possible reasons:
  • The ID in the user_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token is missing the user:read:follows scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.

name: Get Channel Editors
description: Gets the broadcaster’s list editors.
instruction: Gets the broadcaster’s list editors.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:read:editors scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the channel. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

data.instruction: A list of users that are editors for the specified broadcaster. The list is empty if the broadcaster doesn’t have editors.

user_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies a user with editor permissions.

created_at.instruction: The date and time, in RFC3339 format, when the user became one of the broadcaster’s editors.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of editors.
response_codes.400: • The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The OAuth token must include the channel:read:editors scope.

  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.

name: Modify Channel Information
description: Updates a channel’s properties.
instruction: Updates a channel’s properties.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:manage:broadcast scope.

request_body.text: All fields are optional, but you must specify at least one field.

game_id.instruction: The ID of the game that the user plays. The game is not updated if the ID isn’t a game ID that Twitch recognizes. To unset this field, use “0” or “” (an empty string).

broadcaster_language.instruction: The user’s preferred language. Set the value to an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code (for example, en for English). Set to “other” if the user’s preferred language is not a Twitch supported language. The language isn’t updated if the language code isn’t a Twitch supported language.

title.instruction: The title of the user’s stream. You may not set this field to an empty string.

delay.instruction: The number of seconds you want your broadcast buffered before streaming it live. The delay helps ensure fairness during competitive play. Only users with Partner status may set this field. The maximum delay is 900 seconds (15 minutes).

tags.instruction:
A list of channel-defined tags to apply to the channel. To remove all tags from the channel, set tags to an empty array. Tags help identify the content that the channel streams. Learn More

A channel may specify a maximum of 10 tags. Each tag is limited to a maximum of 25 characters and may not be an empty string or contain spaces or special characters. Tags are case insensitive. For readability, consider using camelCasing or PascalCasing.

content_classification_labels.instruction: List of labels that should be set as the Channel’s CCLs.

id.instruction:
ID of the Content Classification Labels that must be added/removed from the channel. Can be one of the following values:
  • DrugsIntoxication
  • SexualThemes
  • ViolentGraphic
  • Gambling
  • ProfanityVulgarity

is_enabled.instruction: Boolean flag indicating whether the label should be enabled (true) or disabled for the channel.

is_branded_content.instruction: Boolean flag indicating if the channel has branded content.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose channel you want to update. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The request must update at least one property.
  • The title field may not contain an empty string.
  • The ID in game_id is not valid.
  • To update the delay field, the broadcaster must have partner status.
  • The list in the tags field exceeds the maximum number of tags allowed.
  • A tag in the tags field exceeds the maximum length allowed.
  • A tag in the tags field is empty.
  • A tag in the tags field contains special characters or spaces.
  • One or more tags in the tags field failed AutoMod review.
  • Game restricted for user's age and region
response_codes.401:
• User requests CCL for a channel they don’t own
  • The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The OAuth token must include the channel:manage:broadcast scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.403:
• User requested gaming CCLs to be added to their channel
  • Unallowed CCLs declared for underaged authorized user in a restricted country
response_codes.409: User set the Branded Content flag too frequently

name: Get Channel Information
description: Gets information about one or more channels.
instruction: Gets information about one or more channels.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster whose channel you want to get. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each broadcaster you want to get. For example, broadcaster_id=1234&broadcaster_id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs. The API ignores duplicate IDs and IDs that are not found.

data.instruction: A list that contains information about the specified channels. The list is empty if the specified channels weren’t found.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

broadcaster_language.instruction: The broadcaster’s preferred language. The value is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code (for example, en for English). The value is set to “other” if the language is not a Twitch supported language.

game_name.instruction: The name of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never played a game.

game_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never played a game.

title.instruction: The title of the stream that the broadcaster is currently streaming or last streamed. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never streamed.

delay.instruction: The value of the broadcaster’s stream delay setting, in seconds. This field’s value defaults to zero unless 1) the request specifies a user access token, 2) the ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter matches the user ID in the access token, and 3) the broadcaster has partner status and they set a non-zero stream delay value.

tags.instruction: The tags applied to the channel.

broadcaster_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the broadcaster.

broadcaster_language.instruction: The broadcaster’s preferred language. The value is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code (for example, en for English). The value is set to “other” if the language is not a Twitch supported language.

game_name.instruction: The name of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never played a game.

game_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never played a game.

title.instruction: The title of the stream that the broadcaster is currently streaming or last streamed. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never streamed.

delay.instruction: The value of the broadcaster’s stream delay setting, in seconds. This field’s value defaults to zero unless 1) the request specifies a user access token, 2) the ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter matches the user ID in the access token, and 3) the broadcaster has partner status and they set a non-zero stream delay value.

tags.instruction: The tags applied to the channel.

content_classification_labels.instruction: The CCLs applied to the channel.

broadcaster_language.instruction: The broadcaster’s preferred language. The value is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code (for example, en for English). The value is set to “other” if the language is not a Twitch supported language.

game_name.instruction: The name of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never played a game.

game_id.instruction: An ID that uniquely identifies the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never played a game.

title.instruction: The title of the stream that the broadcaster is currently streaming or last streamed. The value is an empty string if the broadcaster has never streamed.

delay.instruction: The value of the broadcaster’s stream delay setting, in seconds. This field’s value defaults to zero unless 1) the request specifies a user access token, 2) the ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter matches the user ID in the access token, and 3) the broadcaster has partner status and they set a non-zero stream delay value.

tags.instruction: The tags applied to the channel.

content_classification_labels.instruction: The CCLs applied to the channel.

is_branded_content.instruction: Boolean flag indicating if the channel has branded content.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of channels.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The broadcaster ID is not valid.
  • The number of broadcaster_id query parameters exceeds the maximum allowed.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify an app access token or user access token.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
response_codes.429: • The application exceeded the number of calls it may make per minute. For details, see Rate Limits.

name: Get Extension Transactions
description: Gets an extension’s list of transactions.
instruction: Gets an extension’s list of transactions. A transaction records the exchange of a currency (for example, Bits) for a digital product.
authorization: Requires an app access token.

extension_id.instruction: The ID of the extension whose list of transactions you want to get.

id.instruction: A transaction ID used to filter the list of transactions. Specify this parameter for each transaction you want to get. For example, id=1234&id=5678. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs.

first.instruction: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

after.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

data.instruction: The list of transactions.

id.instruction: An ID that identifies the transaction.

timestamp.instruction: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of the transaction.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the channel where the transaction occurred.

user_id.instruction: The ID of the user that purchased the digital product.

product_type.instruction:
The type of transaction. Possible values are:
  • BITS_IN_EXTENSION

The type of transaction. Possible values are:

name: Get Cheermotes
description: Gets a list of Cheermotes that users can use to cheer Bits.
instruction: Gets a list of Cheermotes that users can use to cheer Bits in any Bits-enabled channel’s chat room. Cheermotes are animated emotes that viewers can assign Bits to.
authorization: Requires an app access token or user access token.

broadcaster_id.instruction:
The ID of the broadcaster whose custom Cheermotes you want to get. Specify the broadcaster’s ID if you want to include the broadcaster’s Cheermotes in the response (not all broadcasters upload Cheermotes). If not specified, the response contains only global Cheermotes.

If the broadcaster uploaded Cheermotes, the type field in the response is set to channel_custom.

data.instruction: The list of Cheermotes. The list is in ascending order by the order field’s value.

prefix.instruction: The name portion of the Cheermote string that you use in chat to cheer Bits. The full Cheermote string is the concatenation of + . For example, if the prefix is “Cheer” and you want to cheer 100 Bits, the full Cheermote string is Cheer100. When the Cheermote string is entered in chat, Twitch converts it to the image associated with the Bits tier that was cheered.

tiers.instruction: A list of tier levels that the Cheermote supports. Each tier identifies the range of Bits that you can cheer at that tier level and an image that graphically identifies the tier level.

prefix.instruction: The name portion of the Cheermote string that you use in chat to cheer Bits. The full Cheermote string is the concatenation of + . For example, if the prefix is “Cheer” and you want to cheer 100 Bits, the full Cheermote string is Cheer100. When the Cheermote string is entered in chat, Twitch converts it to the image associated with the Bits tier that was cheered.

tiers.instruction: A list of tier levels that the Cheermote supports. Each tier identifies the range of Bits that you can cheer at that tier level and an image that graphically identifies the tier level.

min_bits.instruction: The minimum number of Bits that you must cheer at this tier level. The maximum number of Bits that you can cheer at this level is determined by the required minimum Bits of the next tier level minus 1. For example, if min_bits is 1 and min_bits for the next tier is 100, the Bits range for this tier level is 1 through 99. The minimum Bits value of the last tier is the maximum number of Bits you can cheer using this Cheermote. For example, 10000.

id.instruction:
The tier level. Possible tiers are:
  • 1
  • 100
  • 500
  • 1000
  • 5000
  • 10000
  • 100000

color.instruction: The hex code of the color associated with this tier level (for example, #979797).

images.instruction: The animated and static image sets for the Cheermote. The dictionary of images is organized by theme, format, and size. The theme keys are dark and light. Each theme is a dictionary of formats: animated and static. Each format is a dictionary of sizes: 1, 1.5, 2, 3, and 4. The value of each size contains the URL to the image.

can_cheer.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether users can cheer at this tier level.

show_in_bits_card.instruction: A Boolean value that determines whether this tier level is shown in the Bits card. Is true if this tier level is shown in the Bits card.

type.instruction:
The type of Cheermote. Possible values are:
  • global_first_party — A Twitch-defined Cheermote that is shown in the Bits card.
  • global_third_party — A Twitch-defined Cheermote that is not shown in the Bits card.
  • channel_custom — A broadcaster-defined Cheermote.
  • display_only — Do not use; for internal use only.
  • sponsored — A sponsor-defined Cheermote. When used, the sponsor adds additional Bits to the amount that the user cheered. For example, if the user cheered Terminator100, the broadcaster might receive 110 Bits, which includes the sponsor's 10 Bits contribution.

order.instruction: The order that the Cheermotes are shown in the Bits card. The numbers may not be consecutive. For example, the numbers may jump from 1 to 7 to 13. The order numbers are unique within a Cheermote type (for example, global_first_party) but may not be unique amongst all Cheermotes in the response.

last_updated.instruction: The date and time, in RFC3339 format, when this Cheermote was last updated.

is_charitable.instruction: A Boolean value that indicates whether this Cheermote provides a charitable contribution match during charity campaigns.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the Cheermotes.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify an app access token or user access token.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.

name: Get Bits Leaderboard
description: Gets the Bits leaderboard for the authenticated broadcaster.
instruction: Gets the Bits leaderboard for the authenticated broadcaster.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the bits:read scope.

count.instruction: The number of results to return. The minimum count is 1 and the maximum is 100. The default is 10.

period.instruction:
The time period over which data is aggregated (uses the PST time zone). Possible values are:
  • day — A day spans from 00:00:00 on the day specified in started_at and runs through 00:00:00 of the next day.
  • week — A week spans from 00:00:00 on the Monday of the week specified in started_at and runs through 00:00:00 of the next Monday.
  • month — A month spans from 00:00:00 on the first day of the month specified in started_at and runs through 00:00:00 of the first day of the next month.
  • year — A year spans from 00:00:00 on the first day of the year specified in started_at and runs through 00:00:00 of the first day of the next year.
  • all — Default. The lifetime of the broadcaster's channel.

started_at.instruction:
The start date, in RFC3339 format, used for determining the aggregation period. Specify this parameter only if you specify the period query parameter. The start date is ignored if period is all.

Note that the date is converted to PST before being used, so if you set the start time to 2022-01-01T00:00:00.0Z and period to month, the actual reporting period is December 2021, not January 2022. If you want the reporting period to be January 2022, you must set the start time to 2022-01-01T08:00:00.0Z or 2022-01-01T00:00:00.0-08:00.

If your start date uses the ‘+’ offset operator (for example, 2022-01-01T00:00:00.0+05:00), you must URL encode the start date.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies a user that cheered bits in the channel. If count is greater than 1, the response may include users ranked above and below the specified user. To get the leaderboard’s top leaders, don’t specify a user ID.

data.instruction: A list of leaderboard leaders. The leaders are returned in rank order by how much they’ve cheered. The array is empty if nobody has cheered bits.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies a user on the leaderboard.

rank.instruction: The user’s position on the leaderboard.

score.instruction: The number of Bits the user has cheered.

date_range.instruction: The reporting window’s start and end dates, in RFC3339 format. The dates are calculated by using the started_at and period query parameters. If you don’t specify the started_at query parameter, the fields contain empty strings.

user_id.instruction: An ID that identifies a user on the leaderboard.

rank.instruction: The user’s position on the leaderboard.

score.instruction: The number of Bits the user has cheered.

started_at.instruction: The reporting window’s start date.

total.instruction: The number of ranked users in data. This is the value in the count query parameter or the total number of entries on the leaderboard, whichever is less.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s Bits leaderboard.
response_codes.400:
• The time period specified in the period query parameter is not valid.
  • The started_at query parameter is required if period is not set to all.
  • The value in the count query parameter is outside the range of allowed values.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must specify a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the the bits:read scope.
  • The access token is not valid.
  • The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID in the access token.

name: Get Game Analytics
description: Gets an analytics report for one or more games.
instruction: Gets an analytics report for one or more games. The response contains the URLs used to download the reports (CSV files). Learn more
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the analytics:read:games scope.

game_id.instruction: The game’s client ID. If specified, the response contains a report for the specified game. If not specified, the response includes a report for each of the authenticated user’s games.

type.instruction:
The type of analytics report to get. Possible values are:
  • overview_v2

started_at.instruction:
The reporting window’s start date, in RFC3339 format. Set the time portion to zeroes (for example, 2021-10-22T00:00:00Z). If you specify a start date, you must specify an end date.

The start date must be within one year of today’s date. If you specify an earlier date, the API ignores it and uses a date that’s one year prior to today’s date. If you don’t specify a start and end date, the report includes all available data for the last 365 days from today.

The report contains one row of data for each day in the reporting window.

ended_at.instruction:
The reporting window’s end date, in RFC3339 format. Set the time portion to zeroes (for example, 2021-10-22T00:00:00Z). The report is inclusive of the end date.

Specify an end date only if you provide a start date. Because it can take up to two days for the data to be available, you must specify an end date that’s earlier than today minus one to two days. If not, the API ignores your end date and uses an end date that is today minus one to two days.

first.instruction:
The maximum number of report URLs to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 URL per page and the maximum is 100 URLs per page. The default is 20.

NOTE: While you may specify a maximum value of 100, the response will contain at most 20 URLs per page.

after.instruction:
The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

This parameter is ignored if game_id parameter is set.

data.instruction: A list of reports. The reports are returned in no particular order; however, the data within each report is in ascending order by date (newest first). The report contains one row of data per day of the reporting window; the report contains rows for only those days that the game was used. A report is available only if the game was broadcast for at least 5 hours over the reporting period. The array is empty if there are no reports.

game_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the game that the report was generated for.

URL.instruction: The URL that you use to download the report. The URL is valid for 5 minutes.

type.instruction: The type of report.

date_range.instruction: The reporting window’s start and end dates, in RFC3339 format.

URL.instruction: The URL that you use to download the report. The URL is valid for 5 minutes.

type.instruction: The type of report.

date_range.instruction: The reporting window’s start and end dates, in RFC3339 format.

started_at.instruction: The reporting window’s start date.

pagination.instruction: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. Read More

game_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the game that the report was generated for.

URL.instruction: The URL that you use to download the report. The URL is valid for 5 minutes.

started_at.instruction: The reporting window’s start date.

cursor.instruction: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

response_codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s analytics reports.
response_codes.400:
• The start and end dates are optional but if you specify one, you must specify the other.
  • The end date must be equal to or later than the start date.
  • The cursor specified in the after query parameter is not valid.
  • The resource supports only forward pagination (use the after query parameter).
  • The first query parameter is outside the allowed range of values.
response_codes.401:
• The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the analytics:read:games scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The Client-Id header is required.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.
response_codes.404: • The game specified in the game_id query parameter was not found.

name: Get Extension Analytics
description: Gets an analytics report for one or more extensions.
instruction: Gets an analytics report for one or more extensions. The response contains the URLs used to download the reports (CSV files). Learn More
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the analytics:read:extensions scope.

extension_id.instruction: The extension’s client ID. If specified, the response contains a report for the specified extension. If not specified, the response includes a report for each extension that the authenticated user owns.

type.instruction:
The type of analytics report to get. Possible values are:
  • overview_v2

started_at.instruction:
The reporting window’s start date, in RFC3339 format. Set the time portion to zeroes (for example, 2021-10-22T00:00:00Z).

The start date must be on or after January 31, 2018. If you specify an earlier date, the API ignores it and uses January 31, 2018. If you specify a start date, you must specify an end date. If you don’t specify a start and end date, the report includes all available data since January 31, 2018.

The report contains one row of data for each day in the reporting window.

ended_at.instruction:
The reporting window’s end date, in RFC3339 format. Set the time portion to zeroes (for example, 2021-10-27T00:00:00Z). The report is inclusive of the end date.

Specify an end date only if you provide a start date. Because it can take up to two days for the data to be available, you must specify an end date that’s earlier than today minus one to two days. If not, the API ignores your end date and uses an end date that is today minus one to two days.

first.instruction:
The maximum number of report URLs to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 URL per page and the maximum is 100 URLs per page. The default is 20.

NOTE: While you may specify a maximum value of 100, the response will contain at most 20 URLs per page.

after.instruction:
The cursor used to get the next page of results. The Pagination object in the response contains the cursor’s value. Read More

This parameter is ignored if the extension_id parameter is set.

data.instruction: A list of reports. The reports are returned in no particular order; however, the data within each report is in ascending order by date (newest first). The report contains one row of data per day of the reporting window; the report contains rows for only those days that the extension was used. The array is empty if there are no reports.

extension_id.instruction: An ID that identifies the extension that the report was generated for.

URL.instruction: The URL that you use to download the report. The URL is valid for 5 minutes.

type.instruction: The type of report.

name: Start Commercial
description: Starts a commercial on the specified channel.
instruction: Starts a commercial on the specified channel. NOTE: Only partners and affiliates may run commercials and they must be streaming live at the time. NOTE: Only the broadcaster may start a commercial; the broadcaster’s editors and moderators may not start commercials on behalf of the broadcaster.
authorization: Requires a user access token that includes the channel:edit:commercial scope.

broadcaster_id.instruction: The ID of the partner or affiliate broadcaster that wants to run the commercial. This ID must match the user ID found in the OAuth token.

length.instruction: The length of the commercial to run, in seconds. Twitch tries to serve a commercial that’s the requested length, but it may be shorter or longer. The maximum length you should request is 180 seconds.

data.instruction: An array that contains a single object with the status of your start commercial request.

length.instruction: The length of the commercial you requested. If you request a commercial that’s longer than 180 seconds, the API uses 180 seconds.

message.instruction: A message that indicates whether Twitch was able to serve an ad.

retry_after.instruction: The number of seconds you must wait before running another commercial.

response_codes.200: Successfully started the commercial.
response_codes.400:
• The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
  • The length query parameter is required.
  • The ID in broadcaster_id is not valid.
  • To start a commercial, the broadcaster must be streaming live.
  • The broadcaster may not run another commercial until the cooldown period expires. The retry_after field in the previous start commercial response specifies the amount of time the broadcaster must wait between running commercials.
response_codes.401:
• The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the request’s OAuth token.
  • The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
  • The user access token must include the channel:edit:commercial scope.
  • The OAuth token is not valid.
  • The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.
response_codes.404: • The ID in broadcaster_id was not found.
response_codes.429: • The broadcaster may not run another commercial until the cooldown period expires. The retry_after field in the previous start commercial response specifies the amount of time the broadcaster must wait between running commercials.
